Award.AwardTitle: CHS: Small: Collaborative Research: Automating Relevance and Trust Detection in Social Media Data for Emergency Response

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop means to improve information quality and use in emergency response, increasing the value of using messaging and microblogged data from crowds of non-professional participants during disasters. Despite the evidence of strong value to those experiencing the disaster and those seeking information concerning the disaster, there has been very little effort in detecting the relevance and veracity of messages in social media streams. The problem of data verification is one of the largest problems confronting emergency-response organizations contemplating using social media data. This research directly addresses this known problem by methods to measure relevant and verifiable information. The results of this research will have a direct pipeline to organizations involved in emergency response. Therefore the research has the potential to help organizations, which respond to emergencies, make use of large amounts of citizen-produced data, which in turn may improve the speed, quality, and efficiency of emergency response leading to better support to those who need them, and more lives saved.

This research will contribute to the field of Emergency and Disaster Studies by mapping the key decisions made during an emergency response, the information needs, type, form and flow during those decision points, and most importantly, assessing data quality and verifiable standards for each. It will also investigate relevant and verifiable identifiers (or features), provide weights, incorporate these into an analytical framework, and use the results of the analysis as input to scalable computational models. The work will design algorithms that can estimate the relevance and veracity of messages in a high-volume streaming text comprised of short messages. Given the diverse backgrounds of the team, it will contribute to the use and development of socio-technical systems theory to analyze the integration of technical and social systems. The output of the models will match the organizational needs of responding organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Online microblogged data from crowds of non-professional participants during disasters have substantial value to those experiencing a disaster and those seeking information concerning the disaster including disaster officials and policy makers. Still, there has been very little uptake of message data by large-scale, disaster response organizations. Precisely, real-time message data being contributed by those affected by a disaster has not been incorporated into established mechanisms for organizational decision-making. The goal of improving information quality and use in any area of disaster response is challenging due to the overload of information. We aimed at exploring organizationally informed analytical approaches in which we code known social media data and computational approaches to relevant, informative, and actionable message detection from social media streams.

This project led to a suite of key research advances in both social science and computer science as follows: (1) We contributed to the field of Disaster Studies by mapping the key decisions made during a disaster response, the information needs, type, form and flow during those decision points, and most importantly, assessing data quality and verifiable standards for each; (2) We investigated relevant and verifiable identifiers (or features), provided weights, incorporated these into an analytical framework, and used the results of the analysis as input to scalable computational models; (3) Our work produced high-accuracy computational models based on machine learning and deep learning techniques and derived probabilistic estimates of relevant, informative, and actionable messages in a high-volume streaming text comprised of short messages; (4) Given the diverse backgrounds of our team, we contributed to the use and development of socio-technical systems theory to analyze the integration of technical and social systems.

Our research findings have been widely disseminated in top research venues in Web, social media, and disaster management venues. Results from this project have been incorporated into a series of lectures, seminar presentations and invited talks. Research components have been critical parts of graduate courses that have impacted graduate students, and have contributed to the training of many graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students, including female and under-represented populations. Further, this project has supported outreach - through presentations at a museum in Fort Worth.
